intro: Narthecium boreale, commonly known as the northern bladderwort, is a small, herbaceous plant belonging to the family Montiaceae. It is characterized by its rosette of narrow, fleshy leaves that store water, a feature adapted to its wetland or marshy habitat. The plant produces tiny, greenish-yellow flowers that are clustered in dense inflorescences, often appearing in late spring to early summer. Narthecium boreale is typically found in temperate regions, growing in moist soils along the edges of ponds, lakes, and wet meadows. Its unique morphology and habitat preferences make it an interesting subject for botanical study.
